body:
Tranquillity patch at: https://github.com/druid-io/tranquility/pull/213. @niketh are you able to try that out? You can do a build by running:

```
sbt ++2.11.8 'project distribution' universal:packageZipTarball
```
Marking 0.10.0 release notes, this should at least end up there if nothing else. Something along the lines of needing to update tranquility first if you're using that.
@egor-ryashin thanks, fixed to emit only once.
I found a isssue in `Avro` (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AVRO-813). I think it could be the reason. Should we log some to explain it for `Druid` user?
Our data has a granularity of `HOUR`.
Fixed by #4094.

This looks like #4001, a bug that happens with some of the predefined granularities like "day" when your brokers are on 0.9.x and other nodes are on 0.10.0-rc1. It'll be fixed in 0.10.0-rc2.

I think the query you pasted should also work if your brokers are all running 0.10.0-rc1 too.
I only switched one historical node so I don't know if all nodes running 0.10.0-rc1 would work. I'll try this next week.
Is this going to be added to the current 0.10.0-rc1 release as well or is there going to be a rc2?
It'll be part of 0.10.0-rc2.
Any idea on when this will be released?

It'll be when the list of blockers to release (https://github.com/druid-io/druid/milestone/21) is all resolved -- my guess is within a few days. If you want, you could build your own in the meantime, using the 0.10.0 branch.
Oops, closed accidentally.

I don't think there is any metric like that however I think it might be useful to add that. One indirect way is to monitor lag would be to use this metric if you have a realtime pipeline - 
```
ingest/events/messageGap - Time gap between the data time in event and current system time.
```

You can get the currentÂ Kafka offsets that Druid is consuming at using the "Get Supervisor Status Report" API mentioned at http://druid.io/docs/latest/development/extensions-core/kafka-ingestion.html. If you subtract that from the latest offsets in Kafka, you'll get the lag.

It'd definitely be nice for Druid to do that itself, although I believe it currently doesn't.
@leventov I understand this patch may not be perfect but do you see show-stopper issues that we cannot resolve in future releases?

@leventov thanks for clarifying.

This generally looks reasonable, it's kind of complex but I don't see a better way to do type safe metric emitting/filtering/decorating.

Now I have a related question: does the metric handling code really need to be type safe? It seems to me that if we kept some of this structure (like QueryMetricsFactory and DefaultQueryMetrics) but abandoned type safe metric handling, in favor of string keys, then the implementation would be a lot simpler. If we made that change then:

1. We wouldn't need implementations for each query type with query-specific dimensions, reducing and simplifying code.
2. The important functionality remains: site-specific QueryMetricsFactory impls are still able to have full control over whitelisting, blacklisting, adding to, or modifying existing emitted metrics.
3. Site specific QueryMetricsFactory impls wouldn't need to break on each Druid release. This is both good (less work for operators of custom QueryMetricsFactory impls) and potentially bad (no compile-time notification to operators that a new dimension or metric exists). It's still possible for site specific impls to notice this at runtime, and they could perhaps emit an alert or log a warning. And, I can imagine that there would be some QueryMetricsFactory impls that don't _want_ compile time notification enforcement that they handle new dimensions. Maybe all they want to do is add a dimension but not alter existing ones.


I'm not sure if this is better or worse than your current patch, but I would at least like to discuss this non-type-safe option.
@gianm testing this patch in one of the production environment, will let you know once done with the testing.

I raised https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CURATOR-394 with Curator. The root cause of this looks like a Curator bug. In this situation, it should be doable to upgrade Tranquility (the client) first and then Druid (the service), which would work around that Curator issue. It adds to annoyance for users though.

Some questions:

- Should we revert the upgrade to Curator 2.12.0 (#4060) and wait for this to be sorted out upstream? Curator 2.12.0 is supposed to fix #4056, #3837 so there is some downside to reverting. But the upside is that it makes upgrading Druid a lot simpler for Tranquility users, since they don't need to upgrade Tranquility first.
- If we stick with Curator 2.12.0, this issue means that Curator service discovery clients need to be updated before services. I think for Tranquility we can deal with this, but is there anything else in Druid where it'd be difficult to do this?
My feeling is it makes sense to revert the Curator 2.12.0 upgrade.

Thanks @gianm  and @pjain1 for suggestions. Currently I am using way suggested by @gianm but it looks messy and I need to write additional code to send those metrics to graphite or influx. Can you point me direction in druid source where I can add this as part of ingest metrics? I'll give it a try.

If you check out KafkaSupervisor you should be able to find the code that does the status reports. Search for `"currentOffsets"` in the code (one of the keys in the report) to find it.

I think when adding lag, you're going to need to retrieve the latest offsets as well from Kafka, and the most important thing to do there is make sure that this call happens in a way that doesn't block anything else important. Since it's a network call and it might take a while.
Thanks @akashdw, please keep us posted.

@naman-aasaan my guess is this isn't a bug, it seems more likely that you're out of disk space on historicals and that's why data isn't getting loaded. Please double-check that and reopen if you still do think this is a bug.
@praveev are you able to pick this back up?
@b-slim are you able to pick this back up?
@gianm  thanks for review, give me couple of days.

Cool, thanks for the update.

One other suggestion: how about adding a config to S3DataSegmentPusherConfig that controls whether `getPathForHadoop()` uses `s3n` or `s3a`? IMO, it should be s3n by default (for compatibility) but some users would want that to flip over to s3a. Something like `useS3AForHadoop`?

Talking with Jordan on CURATOR-394, it sounds like they may revert their change that broke stuff here, and do another Curator release. So for 0.10.0 I think we should revert back to the older Curator, and then revisit upgrading Curator in 0.10.1. I'll do a patch for that in a bit.
@gianm  tested this patch in one of our environment and I don't see `relocate` issue with `GroupByV2` anymore.
@leventov, that justification makes sense. This patch looks good to me.
@drcrallen do you wish to review changes that I made since you approved this PR?
Spoke with @leventov offline. I'll merge this since it has +1s from me and @himanshug.
Reverted in #4103.
Reopening this issue, since the Curator upgrade was reverted in #4103.
Reopening this issue, since the Curator upgrade was reverted in #4103.
Tagging as 0.10.1 to remind us to look to see if there has been a Curator fix for https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CURATOR-394 when we start working on the 0.10.1 release.
Actually, I'm going to close this in favor of #3837. Both Druid issues are wanting a fix for https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CURATOR-358.
Tagging as 0.10.1 to remind us to look to see if there has been a Curator fix for https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CURATOR-394 when we start working on the 0.10.1 release.

Oh, sorry, I didn't realize this was a duplicate of #3837.

But the title of this one is doubly relevant. *sigh*
@nishantmonu51 reviewed it and @gianm reviewed it so I'm good
Looks good, thanks for the contribution!
@erikdubbelboer RC2 is out now: http://druid.io/downloads.html

@leventov Performance degrades quite a bit with interfaces, unfortunately. Now that I have it working as abstract hierarchies, I'm not sure I want to change it.

Buffer, etc. is now working and with unit test coverage at 96%.
@gianm thanks.
The stack trace looks like you have strings in your avro objects that are really super long.
Yep, it could be. But the length of string must longer than `Integer.MAX_VALUE-2`. I think it cannot happened in my situation.
Is it possible there's some corrupt data or an issue with the avro parser? The stack trace looks like it's more likely one of those two than a problem with druid code.

Maybe... Is it due to https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4100? There are too many nessnary `EOFException` from `ByteBufferInputStream` in `avro`. That will hurt the performance of `tranquility`. I will fix it in our Druid cluster by adding the patch https://issues.apache.org/jira/secure/attachment/12477556/avro-813-patch.txt.
Might be related: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3768

@asdf2014 thanks for the contribution! That's a strange avro bug. Could you include the JIRA link in the exception message too? That way, a user would see it without having to read the Druid code. ð  from me after that.

Also, could you please fill out the CLA here: http://druid.io/community/cla.html

Hmm, maybe rather than going down the road of this patch, a better idea is to stop IncrementalIndexStorageAdapter from returning rows that were created after the cursor was. Then it should be impossible for any values >= maxId to show up in the selector anyway, and it should also fix @kaijianding's original problem from #4049.

@leventov @kaijianding does that sound workable? Maybe we'd make `indexIncrement` accessible somehow and then IncrementalIndexStorageAdapter can use that to have its cursor skip over any rows with higher numbers than existed at the time the cursor was created.

If so: I'm not able to work on that patch right now, but could pick it up later if nobody else has got to it before me.
@leventov @leerho @cheddar @gianm  Lee has finalized the new memory interfaces yesterday. Working on moving the old Memory to the new Memory interfaces.
@gianm Already add the `jira` link into log message. It's my pleasure, i have filled out the individual `CLA`.
@b-slim any more comments?
@gianm I am currently on vacation, I won't be able to get back to this until mid-April.
Got it, no worries, was just checking in. Looking forward to reviewing again when you get back ð
@cheddar @himanshug could this PR be merged now?
@gianm documented it..
@gianm I support your idea.

@kaijianding, see the thread in https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4052#issuecomment-288976998 for a possible solution to your problem that maintains the DimensionSelector contract. I'm not able to work on that patch right now, so if you are able to then go for it. Otherwise I may come back to it later.
:+1: after travis
This is fixed in 0.10.0-rc2.

I guess that means the response context would need to be returned before queries are finished executing, since they won't be done by the time QueryRunner.run returns. Is that ok?

Example: at one point I was thinking we could use the response context for a possible query profiling feature, something that doesn't involve emitting metrics but instead returns a profile in the response itself. That would probably be tough to do with the change you proposed here, since not all profiling info is known at the time QueryRunner.run returns. I don't plan to work on this feature in the near future though, it was just something I thought might be cool.

Also, I think the fact that CachingClusteredClient merges sequences from servers would mean it would have to know how to merge response contexts too.
#3803 does mean that response contexts are not very useful right now, so I agree _something_ needs to change.

@leventov in #3803 you said you were using response contexts for more things -- what were they? Some use cases would illuminate what the behavior should be. Right now, in Druid response contexts aren't used for very much so it's not really clear to me what the best behavior is.
Thanks for confirming!

@asdf2014 unfortunately, sometimes the test fails sporadically. We can re-run them. Although, it looks like this conflicts with your other PR, so could you please resolve those first?

LGTM otherwise. ð

> I guess that means the response context would need to be returned before queries are finished executing, since they won't be done by the time QueryRunner.run returns. Is that ok?

Yes, I forgot that sometimes responseContext is updated *during* the Sequence accumulating. Also AFAIR sometimes it is somehow used *before* sequence is accumulated. So either we need to rethink some logic using responseContext now, or have two responseContexts: "before" and "after", that would be too complex IMO.

In #3803 I was using it to pass what is now known as `QueryMetrics`. However I should have used Query context for this, or add a specific `QueryMetrics` property to `Query`. So I was abusing `responseContext` as well as in #4112.
@Jdban thanks for doing that, fell off my radar.
Do you mean skip over rows whose row number is greater than the one when cursor created? @gianm I think this better solution
Yeah, that's what I mean.

It total could be proved in logic, like releasing those resource of I/O stream etc. And i found no way to put it in practice from the blog (http://druid.io/blog/2014/03/17/benchmarking-druid.html) that content with `queries` and `loading the data` yet not `tranquility with specific extension`.

@knoguchi Shading would be good, I think, since we've had problems with protobuf version conflicts in the past -- in particular with Hadoop.

Also, are you using this in production?

I just [talked about the same issue](https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/druid-user/sNOyoXR5WDE) in the users ML.  One option I thought of is to let KafkaSupervisor report the offsets to the brokers by `consumer.commitSync(Map<TopicPartition,OffsetAndMetadata> offsets)` so that readily available monitoring tools would work.   The offset in the broker is for the monitoring purpose only.  The supervisor should never read them out.   I don't know how high the performance penalty is but this is an optional feature.
@gianm with minor changes in unit test cases it is working fine with Kafka 0.10.2.0 and also updated Kafka indexing service 0.10.x note in docs.
